Indicates whether DFS usage is narrow (mainly remittances) or diversified. High P2P dominance can signal early-stage ecosystems, while declining shares suggest growth in merchant, bill, and government payments.
Measures physical acceptance infrastructure for digital payments.
Tracks low-cost, scalable merchant acceptance, especially important in low-income and informal markets.
Shows two-sided market health. Without merchant acceptance, consumer adoption stacks; this metric reflects real opportunities to spend digitally, not just send money.
Signals cash-in/cash-out access and the strength of the legacy banking interface.
Reflects traditional financial infrastructure depth. Important for understanding geographic access gaps, cost structures, and where digital channels must compensate for limited physical presence.
Measures the inclusion impact of mobile money beyond banks.
Low literacy constrains onboarding, product understanding, and consumer protection, increasing reliance on assisted or agent-based models.
Shows the population’s ability to use digital tools safely and independently.
Links digital adoption to income flows and use cases.
A non-negotiable infrastructure input for digital inclusion.
Captures quality of electricity supply, not just access. Frequent outages undermine service reliability, merchant acceptance, and consumer trust in digital channels.
Measures equity of digital inclusion.
Indicates advanced digital usage and ecosystem growth.
Enables scalable, low-cost onboarding and KYC.
Digitized G2P payments drive account usage and serve as an entry point for first-time users.
